SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name .................................................. Arthur Llewellyn Davies
2. Your address .................................................. 42 Bockalaga West Moose Jaw Saskatchewan Canada
3. Date ................................................................. .
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Haverfordwest Pembrokeshire South Wales
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Thomas Davies Baptist Minister D.D. President Baptist College Haverfordwest
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) When I first came West there was no Saskatchewan
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. In Hull Quebec I lived with a farmer about 20 miles away from Bytown worked for Tom Andy Stevenson for 12 months at $7.00 (seven dollars) a month Bytown-Ottawa
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). I was about Twenty one
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Hired in Winnipeg to survey. The mosquitoes & Black Flies were very bad
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). Government information pamphlets. Got this information through them which showed different stages of occupations
Davies, Arthur Llewellyn,
42 Hochelaga St., W.,
Moose Jaw, about 1912.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

FLOWER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you do not remember how someone else does the writing at your district, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Arthur Llewellyn Davies
2. Year address: 42 Hochelaga, but house near the Saskatchewan Canada.
3. Date:
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and date)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. I heard with a former name to make away from Regina.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child")
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people, newspaper about 1917, Railhead or government information pamphlet, got this information through there)

Government information pamphlet, got this information through there which showed different stages of development
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They thought or rather they said it was adventurous.

My first letter after arriving in Bytown was from my mother.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
Two other Welshmen joined me when I left Haverfordwest.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Went to Liverpool and boarded the Circassian for the trip across the Ocean.

I was met in Hull by my cousin who was learning to be a doctor. I stayed for a few days there. Later I got a job on a farm at seven dollars a month. The farmer's name was Tom Andy Stevenson. He kept a number of cows. He raised me early in the morning saying "Arthur, are you going to stay in bed all day?"

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
An incident of my road journey was the hard usage of traveller's baggage.

On our journey we made Winnipeg a stopping place. At that time there was a large number of people living in tents outside of Winnipeg proper. Our tent was on its way to Winnipeg from Ottawa. We stretched blankets over poles until the tent arrived. We caught gophers on the Red River and unloaded corn for a living.

Later we bought a yoke of oxen each and entered for land. We joined up with Gurney who had some experience in English farming. We put up shacks made of sods covered by long grass. Our first shack took fire and we hastily threw everything out and headed for an empty shack about a mile away over deep snow.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
We were landed overseas and Phillips got his toes frozen. We made for Moose Jaw Crossing.

And obtained a sleeping place on the floor of Haunted upper room floor. We had a dry goods box where all mail was thrown for every inmate into a box on the floor, to hunt for letters and papers addressed to him. One day a party of men came in for dinner; one of them had a cough. Our Landlord and one other in that crowd has not long to live. They were very down who became wealthy farmers a few months back of Moose Jaw and became later a big farmer & was made mayor of Moose Jaw.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
We settled for 160 acres about 9 miles North.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan?

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
Phillips with frozen feet had to lay up. At Pitt Lake took care of him. I worked on the section and I hauled a hen house from the farm. 8 x 10. Angus Watson and Phillips and myself slept in tents at one end of the shack. Indians who had come over from the Custer massacre and who camped in the shelter of a grove under a chief called Tatanka-Sapa became friendly and they had a young fellow who we named Alexander. We hired several ponies & jumped and started when it was 30 below zero on a trip to Waparawas village. The young Moose Jaw farmer on whose land we camped went back to his neighbors and said there are 3 boys camping on my slough who will never come back.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)? Yes, my family joined me when I came here.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Went to Liverpool and traveled the Circumnavigation for the trip across the ocean.

14. What memories do you have of the journey? We met Indians on the journey, adventures on the journey, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, etc.

On our journey we made Winnipeg a stopping place. At that time there was a large number of people living in tents outside of Winnipeg proper.

Our tent was on its way to Winnipeg from Ontario. We started about three days after we left Philadelphia. We arrived at the Red River and remained there until the boat arrived. We bought groceries on the boat.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We stayed in a hotel in Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? We settled near a small town.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. We lived in Regina for a short time.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? I worked on the Pacific Coast before I came here.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Not very often.

I made a trip to Newfounland and found I was in love with a young girl I had known before I left. My father told me she is no mate for you, Miss Ruttell is the one for you.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My wife's name was Susan Amanda Ruttell. Before her marriage to me, I met her first when she was teaching school. J.K. Ruttell said she is the girl for you. J.K. Ruttell was a leading farmer.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

I have an announcement as follows—“Educationalists from many countries visit Perth (Australia). But none of them settled. I believe they all returned to England or Scotland or Ireland or other native countries.”

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

The first church service held at the Moore farm crossing was under the lead of Rev. Mr. Bristol, known as Bristol Bill. Nearly all who attended were settlers from around the town and surrounding farms.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

I wrote very often and I visited them frequently.

20. If you got married, tell me the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My wife's name was Jane Smith and we got married on January 1st, 1850 in London, England.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yes, my brother came with me.

22. Tell other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) where they settled.

My brothers settled in Ontario, my sisters in Quebec, and my parents in New Brunswick.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory?

The first church service held at the pioneer school was under the leadership of Reverend John Brown, who came from around the town area.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Yes, I traveled quite a bit for business purposes.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Never owned a car, with one exception.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   8 miles from first farm.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   They used to drive in by horse or oxen.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Lived on salt pork, flour & black strap (spirits).

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Came with a view to permanent settlement.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some men said the country had too many mosquitoes for white men.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Quite a few. They went back to a civilized country.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

for which reason.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

We had eleven children of whom 3 passed away. One a baby called Dorothy, a married daughter Mrs. Johnston, and a son who

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The first important change was the adoption of second homesteads. A neighbour got up a memorial to the Canadian Government asking for adoption of second homesteads.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

The pioneers whom I knew have all passed away. I am now 91 years of age.

30. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have any personal or family records? If so, do you know where they are located? (e.g., old letters, photos, diaries, etc.)

Would you be willing to donate them to the Provincial Archives for preservation?

(1) Yes
(2) No

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, ages, and occupations.

We had three children: John, Robert, and Sarah.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

The most important change was the adoption of second homesites.

A neighbour got up a memorial to the Canadian government allowing for adoption of second homesites.

In company with four others I applied for employment by providing horses, saddle, rifle & other necessities such as oats for our horses & food for ourselves etc. We volunteered to go up to Willow Bunch at the beginning of the Riel Rebellion. The 4 were Sam McFetridge and myself.

The first house we came to was Jaur Wickey. It was a well educated French man who said "Wickey" you say. He looked at our guns and said "Loaded Eh?"

Then we went on to Willow Bunch. A bunch of half breeds who had been suspected of being disloyal came up in force with guns and put up a stake in the ground & a small bottle on the top and dared us to shoot. We shot a few times and missed every time. The one sharp shooter shot once and broke the bottle. They then tuned up fiddles and danced in good time. We went down and fed our horses and had our supper and then were told to occupy the priest's room for the night.
In company with four others I applied for employment by providing various saddle rope & other supplies as well as work for our horses & feed for ourselves & ours. We volunteered to go to William's Branch at the beginning of the Red Rebellion.

The next day we came to Ben's Bridge. He was a well educated man who said "I looked Ed" and "I will probably go."

Then we went on to Willmar Branch. A bunch of half breed who had been suspected of being disloyal came up in force with guns and put up a stake in the ground & a small bottle on the top and dared us to shoot. He shot a few times and missed every time.

The men always shoot at least once and finish the bottle. They then turned up fielded and danced in great time. We went down and got our horses and took our supper and then went back to occupy the priory room for the night.
